answer_html: By part c, we see immediately that concavity changes from concave up to concave down at the point \(x = 7/2\).This is the only inflection point.
answer_latex:
By part c, we see immediately that concavity changes from concave up to
concave down at the point $x = 7/2$.This is the only inflection point.
hints_html: Use the solution to part c and recall that inflection points are points in the domain of the function where the second derivative changes sign.
hints_latex:
Use the solution to part c and recall that inflection points are points
in the domain of the function where the second derivative changes sign.
hints_raw: Use the solution to part c and recall that inflection points are points in the domain of the function where the second derivative changes sign.
question: 6 (d)
sols_html: By part c, we see immediately that concavity changes from concave up to concave down at the point \(x = 7/2\). This is the only inflection point.
sols_latex:
By part c, we see immediately that concavity changes from concave up to
concave down at the point $x = 7/2$. This is the only inflection point.
sols_raw: By part c, we see immediately that concavity changes from concave up to concave down at the point <math> x = 7/2 </math>. This is the only inflection point.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 5-11, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions.

6. Let \(f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}\). Note that the domain of \(f\) is the set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, \(f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1\).

(d) Find the x-coordinates of all inflection points of \(f(x)\).
statement_latex:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problems}. In questions 5-11, justify your answers
and \textbf{show all your work}. If a box is provided, write your final
answer there. \textbf{Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of
numerical answers is required in these questions.}

6. Let $f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}$. Note that the domain of $f$ is the
set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, $f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1$.

(d) Find the \emph{x}-coordinates of all inflection points of $f(x)$.

'''Full-Solution Problems'''. In questions 5-11, justify your answers and '''show all your work'''. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. '''Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these  questions.'''

6. Let <math>f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}</math>. Note that the domain of &fnof; is the set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, <math>f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1</math>.

(d) Find the ''x''-coordinates of all inflection points of <math>f(x)</math>.
